p.seg: It was already two years since king Cheng had enfeoffed the Duke of Zhou,
and the king held his position in great esteem [or: as a heavy burden],
and so he visited him in [...]
[...] arrival,
to the east of Zhou,
and then instructed him saying:
“In the past there was a spiritual way,
so great! so pure!
If one wants to lift it, it would be in vain,
and (trying) to advance (it) would lead to wounds [=it is so perfect that cannot be improved upon(?)].
Once one has reached it,
one cannot be damaged,
it is not possible to destroy him,
its appearance is lofty and majestic, rich and deep [...]
[...] (I) want to understand it clearly.
The duke of Zhou said:
“As I have heard,
in each case it resided in them,
and in all cases they showed its radiance to Heaven.”
King Cheng said:
“As for the way of Zeng of Xia,
it allows to know what is beneficial and what is not,
what perishes and what lasts,
(but) can this be said to possess the (real) way?”
The duke of Zhou said:
“This is (simply) the refinement of the two aforementioned things [the knowledge about ability/expediency and about lasting],
it is illustrious among the external methods,
but it is lowly and inadequate to (the cultivation of) the self,
it is not the just way of the Son of Heaven.”
King Cheng said:
“May I ask about the just way of the Son of Heaven?”
The Duke of Zhou said:
“[When the people] all want to leave their own relatives and get near to him,
when they all want to come to him with their own states,
this is the just way of the Son of Heaven.
[Then] they come on their own without being summoned,
[the government] is perfect on its own without the need of scrutinizing it,
and [the people] submit themselves to justice without cruel punishments.
King Cheng said:
“May I ask about its implementation?”
[...] and the worthies are able, through the protection of these six treasures, to obtain personal allegiance (from them),
this is called the bound of the six personal relationships.
King Cheng said:
“May I ask what is its recipe?”
The Duke of Zhou said [...]
[...] and don’t we say:
“The sun radiates and the ice melts?”
King Cheng said:
“Oh! The way [...]
[...] terrible calamity.
The wickedness of this terrible calamity
is just to be expected.
All these six things are cases of disobedience.
The people in all cases are pervaded by an estranged spirit,
and the states are bent on mutual harm and destruction,
this is what is called a terrible calamity.
A terrible calamity [...]
They protect the august and bright virtue of its lineage (?)
The king was in Gao,
he summoned Dan the Duke of Zhou and said:
“Oh! Treat him with respect!
I have heard that in [the past] [...]
